Sweat Lodge

A sweat lodge is a small domed hut used by various North American Indigenous cultures for dry heat sessions, similar to a sauna. The religious traditions surrounding these sessions, often referred to simpy as 'sweats', differ greatly between nations, but often include purification and initiation rituals.

Dar-e Mehr

The Zoroastrian Fire Temples, or Dar-e Mehr, were the centers of Persian religious life. Water and fire are honoured as the main components of ritual purification in Zoroatrianism. Fire, Atar, is held in special regard as the manifestation of Ahura Mazda, the singular creator god of Zoroastrianism. The altar inside the Dar-e Mehr is kept perpetually lit and purifying ash from the fire is used in the priests' various rituals.

Gurdwaras
Use [ICON_PEACE] Faith to purchase Gurdwaras.
Gurdwara

A Gurdwara -- which means "door to the guru" -- is the place of worship for Sikhs. All gurdwaras contain the holy Sikh scripture, the Guru Granth Sahib, placed on an elevated platform. From this platform, a Raagis recites, sings, and explains the scripture for the congregation. The other universal feature of all gurdwaras is a community kitchen called a Langar. Sikhs place great importance on serving free vegetarian meals, allowing all community members, regardless of ethnicity, caste, status or religion, to both eat and volunteer free of charge.

A Daoguan is a place of worship in Taoism. The structure and function of a Daoguan can vary according to the Taoist school the temple belongs to. For example, guan of the Quanzhen School are monasteries where celibate daoshi live.
